core_requirement:
Lithium-ion secondary batteries and battery systems shall comply with the following safety and classification requirements:

a) Battery Safety Standard Compliance: Lithium-ion secondary batteries shall meet the safety requirements specified in IEC 62133-2 or equivalent recognized standards for lithium-ion secondary battery safety.

b) UN Transport Classification: Lithium-ion batteries and battery-equipped vehicles shall be classified and handled according to the appropriate United Nations transport classification as follows:
   1) Lithium-ion batteries (standalone): UN 3480
   2) Lithium-ion batteries contained in equipment: UN 3481
   3) Lithium-ion batteries packed with equipment: UN 3481
   4) Battery-powered vehicle or battery-powered equipment (including light electric vehicles): UN 3171
   5) Hybrid electric vehicle (HEV): UN 3166

c) Light Electric Vehicle Classification: For light electric vehicles (e-bikes, e-scooters, etc.), the UN 3171 classification for "Battery-powered vehicle or battery powered equipment" applies and shall be used for transport documentation and handling procedures.

a) Fire and Explosion: The DUT shall exhibit no evidence of fire or explosion at any time during the test or observation period.

g) Continuous Charge Testing: During continuous charge at constant voltage, the DUT shall not exhibit leakage, fire, or explosion.

differences_across_standards.difference_summary: EN 50604-1 provides more detailed and varied acceptance criteria across different test types, including specific observation periods (1 hour vs 6 hours), isolation resistance requirements for voltage class B DUT (100 Ω/V), and explicit inclusion of 'disassembly' and 'enclosure rupture' as failure modes. Different clauses specify different combinations of failure modes depending on the test context.

IEC 62133-2 uses simpler, more uniform acceptance criteria across multiple test sections, consistently requiring 'no fire, no explosion' with some tests also including 'no leakage'. Does not specify post-test observation periods or isolation resistance requirements. Includes specific criterion for continuous charge at constant voltage.

core_requirement:
Test sample preparation, monitoring, and observation shall comply with the following requirements:

a) Sample Preparation and Mounting:
   1) Samples shall be prepared according to the specific test requirements, with additional preparation details provided where applicable for clarity
   2) For mechanical tests requiring fixturing, the fully charged sample shall be secured to the testing machine by means of a rigid mount that supports all mounting surfaces of the sample
   3) For cleaning tests, the sample shall be rubbed for 15 seconds with a piece of cloth soaked with petroleum spirit

b) State of Charge:
   1) Tests shall be conducted on fully charged devices under test (DUT) at manufacturer's specified maximum state of charge (MOSOC)
   2) The fully charged condition shall be maintained unless otherwise specified by the particular test procedure

c) Test Execution Parameters:
   1) For thermal exposure tests, the sample shall be placed in a full-draft circulating-air oven maintained at a uniform temperature of 70°C (158°F), with samples remaining in the oven for 7 hours
   2) For rotation tests, the fully charged sample shall be rotated at a continuous rate of 90°/15 seconds, conducting testing by subjecting the sample to a 360° rotation in 3 mutually perpendicular different directions; devices with only 2 axes of symmetry (such as cylindrical designs) shall be subjected to 2 mutually perpendicular directions of rotation
   3) For crush tests, the sample shall be crushed between a fixed surface and a ribbed test platen having semi-cylindrical intruders with a 75-mm (2.95-in) radius placed 30-mm (1.2-in) from one another across the face of the platen
   4) For impact tests, a 15.8 mm diameter bar shall be placed across the test sample cell or component cell, then a 9.1 kg mass shall be dropped from a height of 61 cm onto the bar
   5) For tests requiring concrete surfaces, the concrete surface shall be at least 76-mm (3-in) thick and shall be large enough in area to cover the DUT

d) Monitoring and Observation:
   1) During testing, the open circuit voltage (OCV) of the sample and temperatures on the center cell(s/modules) may be monitored for information purposes
   2) Temperature monitoring on the center cell shall be conducted for information purposes where applicable
   3) For impact and similar tests, samples shall be observed for 6 hours following the test event
   4) Monitoring for information purposes should be conducted during rotation testing

e) Temperature Measurement Accuracy:
   1) Temperature measurements shall maintain accuracy of ±2°C (±3.6°F) for temperatures at or below 200°C (392°F)
   2) Temperature measurements shall maintain accuracy of ±3% for temperatures above 200°C (392°F)

f) Fire Propagation Test Setup:
   1) Cheesecloth (bleached cotton cloth of approximately 40 g/m²) shall be placed 100 mm distance above the DUT
   2) After the test, this cheesecloth shall remain intact

g) Acceptance Criteria:
   1) As a result of testing, there shall be no fire propagating from the DUT or explosion of the DUT
   2) The deterioration of the devices under evaluation shall not result in unacceptable properties (i.e., reduced performance that would result in malfunction of the connection)
   3) The deterioration shall not be greater than that of the comparison design where applicable

h) Documentation and Guidance:
   1) Conformity can be checked by examination of manufacturer's documentation
   2) Guidance on design and manufacture shall be referenced from applicable technical reports and informative annexes

core_requirement:
Test equipment and materials for safety testing shall conform to the following specifications:

a) Test Finger Probe (for accessibility testing):
   1) Dimensions: As specified in EN 61032:1998, Figure 2, test probe B, but without joints
   2) Material: Metal, except where otherwise specified
   3) Tolerances (for dimensions without specified tolerances):
      - Angles: +0° / -10°
      - Linear dimensions ≤25 mm: +0 mm / -0.05 mm
      - Linear dimensions >25 mm: ±0.2 mm
   4) All linear dimensions are in millimetres

b) Nickel Particle (for internal short circuit testing):
   1) Shape: L-shaped as shown in applicable standard figures
   2) Dimensions:
      - Height: 0.2 mm
      - Thickness: 0.1 mm
      - L-shape angle: 90° ±10°
      - Each side of L-shape: 1.0 mm with 5% tolerance
   3) Material: More than 99% pure nickel (mass fraction)

c) Nickel Particle Insertion Procedure for Cylindrical Cells:
   1) Insertion between positive active material zone and negative active material zone:
      i) IF the outer turn of the positive substrate is aluminum foil, cut the foil at the separation line between the aluminum foil and active material to perform short circuit test between positive and negative active materials
      ii) Insert the nickel particle between the positive active material and the separator
      iii) Alignment: As shown in applicable standard figures
      iv) Position: 20 mm from the edge of the aluminum foil cut
      v) Direction: L-shaped corner in the winding direction
   2) Insertion between positive aluminum foil (uncoated zone) and negative coated zone (active material):
      i) WHEN positive electrode aluminum foil is exposed on the outer turn and faces the negative active material coating, use the following procedure
      ii) WHEN positive electrode aluminum foil is exposed on the outer turn, cut the aluminum foil 10 mm from the separation line between the aluminum foil and active material
      iii) Insert the nickel particle between the aluminum foil and the separator
      iv) Alignment: As shown in applicable standard figures
      v) Position: 1.0 mm from the edge of the positive active material coating on the aluminum foil
   3) Mark the position of the nickel particle on both ends of the wound core separator using the following procedure:
      i) Place insulating sheet between the separator facing the nickel particle and the negative electrode to protect against short circuits
      ii) Manually wind the electrodes and separator while holding the nickel particle in place and apply adhesive tape to the wound core
      iii) Mark the position of the nickel particle on the wound core
      iv) Place the wound core in a zip-lock polyethylene bag and seal it tightly
      v) Place the polyethylene bag in an aluminum laminated bag to prevent drying
      vi) Complete the procedure within 30 minutes

d) Nickel Particle Insertion Procedure for Prismatic Cells:
   1) Before inserting the nickel particle, place an insulating sheet between the negative electrode and the separator located below the nickel particle and the negative electrode to protect against short circuits
   2) Insertion between positive coated zone (active material) and negative coated zone (active material):
      i) Insert the nickel particle between the positive coated zone (active material) and the separator OR between the separator and the negative coated zone (active material)
      ii) FOR aluminum cell cases, insert the nickel particle between the positive coated zone (active material) and the separator
      iii) Insert the nickel particle between the positive active material and the separator
      iv) Alignment: As shown in applicable standard figures
      v) Position: Center (diagonally) of the wound core
      vi) Direction: L-shaped corner of the nickel particle in the winding direction

e) Nickel Particle Positioning Recommendations:
   1) WHEN the nickel particle cannot be placed in the position described above, the position may be modified
   2) FOR prismatic cells, a nickel particle may be placed on a flat surface, but it shall be positioned at the center of the surface under pressure
   3) IF it is difficult to place a nickel particle under the outermost layer, it may be placed under an inner layer as shown in applicable standard figures
   4) A nickel particle shall NOT be placed in a zone where the positive active material has detached from the aluminum foil
   5) IF material has detached in the specified zone, place the nickel particle in another zone where positive active material exists and where it can be compressed (with the center of the pressure clamping jig)
   6) The position of the nickel particle may be determined by the cell manufacturer and the test technician

f) Test Preparation and Packaging:
   1) Disassemble the charged cell as specified in applicable procedures
   2) Place one wound core in one zip-lock polyethylene bag, then place in one aluminum laminated bag
   3) To minimize electrolyte vaporization, use bags as small as possible (example: polyethylene bag 100 mm width × 140 mm height × 0.04 mm thickness; aluminum laminated bag 120 mm width × 180 mm height × 0.11 mm thickness)
   4) Set oven temperature as specified in applicable test requirements
   5) Place the wound core and nickel particle in an aluminum foil bag and place in the oven for 45 minutes ±15 minutes
   6) Remove the wound core from the sealed bag and attach voltage measurement leads and thermocouple for temperature to the surface of the wound core
   7) Place the wound core in the mounting jig to locate the position of the nickel particle under the press
   8) Remove the insulating sheet and close the oven door

group_title: Test Probe and Nickel Particle Specifications for Internal Short Circuit Testing
regulatory_intent: These clauses collectively specify the precise dimensional, material, and procedural requirements for test probes and nickel particles used in safety testing. The test finger probe is used for accessibility testing to ensure hazardous parts are not reachable, while the nickel particle specifications enable controlled internal short circuit testing of lithium-ion cells to verify their safety response under fault conditions.
consolidated_requirement:
Test equipment and materials for safety testing shall conform to the following specifications:

a) Test Finger Probe (for accessibility testing):
   1) Dimensions: As specified in EN 61032:1998, Figure 2, test probe B, but without joints
   2) Material: Metal, except where otherwise specified
   3) Tolerances (for dimensions without specified tolerances):
      - Angles: +0° / -10°
      - Linear dimensions ≤25 mm: +0 mm / -0.05 mm
      - Linear dimensions >25 mm: ±0.2 mm
   4) All linear dimensions are in millimetres

b) Nickel Particle (for internal short circuit testing):
   1) Shape: L-shaped as shown in applicable standard figures
   2) Dimensions:
      - Height: 0.2 mm
      - Thickness: 0.1 mm
      - L-shape angle: 90° ±10°
      - Each side of L-shape: 1.0 mm with 5% tolerance
   3) Material: More than 99% pure nickel (mass fraction)

c) Nickel Particle Insertion Procedure for Cylindrical Cells:
   1) Insertion between positive active material zone and negative active material zone:
      i) IF the outer turn of the positive substrate is aluminum foil, cut the foil at the separation line between the aluminum foil and active material to perform short circuit test between positive and negative active materials
      ii) Insert the nickel particle between the positive active material and the separator
      iii) Alignment: As shown in applicable standard figures
      iv) Position: 20 mm from the edge of the aluminum foil cut
      v) Direction: L-shaped corner in the winding direction
   2) Insertion between positive aluminum foil (uncoated zone) and negative coated zone (active material):
      i) WHEN positive electrode aluminum foil is exposed on the outer turn and faces the negative active material coating, use the following procedure
      ii) WHEN positive electrode aluminum foil is exposed on the outer turn, cut the aluminum foil 10 mm from the separation line between the aluminum foil and active material
      iii) Insert the nickel particle between the aluminum foil and the separator
      iv) Alignment: As shown in applicable standard figures
      v) Position: 1.0 mm from the edge of the positive active material coating on the aluminum foil
   3) Mark the position of the nickel particle on both ends of the wound core separator using the following procedure:
      i) Place insulating sheet between the separator facing the nickel particle and the negative electrode to protect against short circuits
      ii) Manually wind the electrodes and separator while holding the nickel particle in place and apply adhesive tape to the wound core
      iii) Mark the position of the nickel particle on the wound core
      iv) Place the wound core in a zip-lock polyethylene bag and seal it tightly
      v) Place the polyethylene bag in an aluminum laminated bag to prevent drying
      vi) Complete the procedure within 30 minutes

d) Nickel Particle Insertion Procedure for Prismatic Cells:
   1) Before inserting the nickel particle, place an insulating sheet between the negative electrode and the separator located below the nickel particle and the negative electrode to protect against short circuits
   2) Insertion between positive coated zone (active material) and negative coated zone (active material):
      i) Insert the nickel particle between the positive coated zone (active material) and the separator OR between the separator and the negative coated zone (active material)
      ii) FOR aluminum cell cases, insert the nickel particle between the positive coated zone (active material) and the separator
      iii) Insert the nickel particle between the positive active material and the separator
      iv) Alignment: As shown in applicable standard figures
      v) Position: Center (diagonally) of the wound core
      vi) Direction: L-shaped corner of the nickel particle in the winding direction

e) Nickel Particle Positioning Recommendations:
   1) WHEN the nickel particle cannot be placed in the position described above, the position may be modified
   2) FOR prismatic cells, a nickel particle may be placed on a flat surface, but it shall be positioned at the center of the surface under pressure
   3) IF it is difficult to place a nickel particle under the outermost layer, it may be placed under an inner layer as shown in applicable standard figures
   4) A nickel particle shall NOT be placed in a zone where the positive active material has detached from the aluminum foil
   5) IF material has detached in the specified zone, place the nickel particle in another zone where positive active material exists and where it can be compressed (with the center of the pressure clamping jig)
   6) The position of the nickel particle may be determined by the cell manufacturer and the test technician

f) Test Preparation and Packaging:
   1) Disassemble the charged cell as specified in applicable procedures
   2) Place one wound core in one zip-lock polyethylene bag, then place in one aluminum laminated bag
   3) To minimize electrolyte vaporization, use bags as small as possible (example: polyethylene bag 100 mm width × 140 mm height × 0.04 mm thickness; aluminum laminated bag 120 mm width × 180 mm height × 0.11 mm thickness)
   4) Set oven temperature as specified in applicable test requirements
   5) Place the wound core and nickel particle in an aluminum foil bag and place in the oven for 45 minutes ±15 minutes
   6) Remove the wound core from the sealed bag and attach voltage measurement leads and thermocouple for temperature to the surface of the wound core
   7) Place the wound core in the mounting jig to locate the position of the nickel particle under the press
   8) Remove the insulating sheet and close the oven door

core_requirement:
For internal short circuit testing of lithium-ion cells, nickel particles shall be prepared and inserted according to the following requirements:

a) Nickel Particle Shape and Dimensions:
   - The shape of the nickel particle shall conform to the standardized L-shaped configuration as specified in the applicable test standard figures
   - Dimensions shall match the completed nickel particle specifications provided in the standard

b) Material and Tools:
   - Use materials and tools as specified in the preparation procedure
   - Follow the example nickel particle preparation procedure provided in the standard

c) Insertion Procedure for Cylindrical Cells:
   - Between positive and negative active material coated areas:
     i) Insert nickel particle between positive active material and separator
     ii) Align the nickel particle as shown in the standard figures
     iii) Position the insertion of the nickel particle 20 mm from the edge of the cut aluminium foil
     iv) Direct the L-shaped corner towards the direction of winding
   - Between positive aluminium foil (uncoated area) and negative active material coated area:
     i) When aluminium foil of positive electrode is exposed at outer turn and facing the coated negative active material, cut off the aluminium foil 10 mm from the dividing line between aluminium foil and active material
     ii) Insert nickel particle between aluminium foil and separator
     iii) Align the nickel particle as shown in the standard figures
     iv) Position the insertion of nickel particle at 1.0 mm from the edge of the coating of positive active material on aluminium foil

d) Insertion Procedure for Prismatic Cells:
   - Follow the insertion positions specified for prismatic cell configurations between positive and negative coated areas and between positive aluminium foil and negative coated areas as shown in the standard figures

e) Positioning and Placement:
   - Position the nickel particle according to the specified placement procedures
   - IF the nickel particle cannot be placed in the specified area, follow the alternative positioning guidance provided in the standard

f) Quality Control:
   - Test samples should have passed the quality control procedure of the supplier
   - The supplier should provide a quality examination report

g) Cell Disassembly:
   - Follow the disassembly procedures specified for cylindrical and prismatic cells as applicable

core_requirement:
The following protective equipment and grounding requirements shall be implemented:

a) Personnel Protective Equipment: During testing and handling operations, personnel shall wear:
   1) Long sleeved protective clothing
   2) Protective glasses
   3) Mask
   4) Gloves

b) Protective Grounding System (applicable to electric energy storage assemblies having a protective grounding system):
   1) A continuity check of the grounding conductors shall be conducted on 100% of production units employing protective grounding, using an ohmmeter or other suitable method
   2) The continuity check shall determine that the resistance of the protective grounding system does not exceed 0.1Ω
   3) The test evaluates the continuity of the protective grounding system to ensure proper electrical safety
   4) Testing may be conducted at the module level that is representative of the energy storage assembly

core_requirement:
The following requirements shall be met for battery cells, components, materials, and documentation:

a) Mechanical Shock Testing for Battery Cells: Battery cells shall be subjected to mechanical shock testing with the following parameters:
   - Waveform: Half sine
   - Peak acceleration: 150 g
   - Pulse duration: 6 ms
   - Number of shocks per half axis: 3

b) Material Compatibility: Materials used in battery construction shall be evaluated for compatibility according to the Metal Compatibility Table (reference applicable standard's material compatibility requirements to prevent galvanic corrosion, chemical reactions, or other material incompatibilities that could create safety hazards).

c) Component and Subsystem Certificates: Certificates for components and subsystems shall be delivered with the Device Under Test (DUT). Required certificates shall be provided as specified in the applicable standard's certificate requirements table, demonstrating that components and subsystems meet relevant safety standards.

differences_across_standards.difference_summary: Specifies detailed mechanical shock test parameters specifically for battery cells (150g peak acceleration, 6ms pulse duration, half sine waveform, 3 shocks per half axis). This is a specific test requirement rather than a general documentation or material compatibility requirement.

Provides a Metal Compatibility Table for evaluating material combinations in battery construction. This is a material selection and compatibility assessment requirement rather than a testing or documentation requirement.

Requires delivery of certificates for components and subsystems with the DUT, with specific certificate types detailed in Table 1. This is a documentation and traceability requirement rather than a testing or material requirement.

   2) Covers the entire production process for each type of battery
   3) Demonstrates understanding of processing capabilities
   4) Establishes necessary process controls concerning product safety

   1) HEAT AND FIRE EXPOSURE: Do not expose cells or batteries to heat or fire. Avoid storage directly under sunlight.

   4) POLARITY MARKING: Equipment should be designed to prevent incorrect insertion of cells or batteries and should have clearly distinct polarity markings. Always respect the polarity markings on the cell, battery, and equipment and ensure correct use.
   5) DEDICATED CHARGER: A dedicated charger should be provided for each device. Complete charging instructions should be provided for all batteries offered for sale.

h) PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT FOR HANDLING: When handling batteries (particularly during testing, disassembly, or maintenance operations), wear protective clothing with long sleeves, protective glasses, a mask, and gloves.

i) DROP TEST REQUIREMENTS: Free drop testing shall be performed at ambient temperature of 20°C ± 5°C using cells or batteries charged to fully charged state according to the first procedure of clause 7.1.1. Each cell or battery shall be dropped three times from a height of 1.0 m onto a flat concrete floor or metal floor. The drop of cells or batteries shall be performed to obtain shocks in random orientations. After testing, the cell or battery shall be rested for a minimum of 1 hour and then a visual examination shall be performed.

j) BATTERY RECONDITIONING EVALUATION: For battery reconditioning or transformation, evaluation shall be performed in accordance with UL 1974.

core_requirement:
The manufacturer shall specify and document the normal operating region for lithium-ion secondary cells, which defines the voltage, current, and temperature ranges within which the cell can be safely charged and discharged repetitively throughout its anticipated life. The normal operating region shall include the following parameters:

a) For charging:
   1) Upper limit charging voltage: The highest charging voltage limit in the normal operating region. For lithium-ion cells employing lithium cobalt oxide as the positive active material and carbon as the negative material, the upper limit charging voltage is typically 4.25 V (permissible upper limit from a safety viewpoint), unless a different voltage is specified based on the cell manufacturer's specifications.
   2) Maximum charging current: The maximum charging current in the normal operating region.
   3) Upper limit charging temperature range.
   4) IF the maximum charging parameters (voltage, current, or temperature limits) vary with temperature, the correspondence between charging parameters and temperature shall be clearly specified in the charging instructions.

b) For discharging:
   1) Lower limit discharge voltage: The minimum voltage to which the cell may be safely discharged.
   2) Maximum discharge current in the normal operating region.
   3) Operating temperature range for discharging.

c) IF an upper limit charging voltage different from the standard values (e.g., other than 4.25 V for lithium cobalt oxide cells) is to be applied, the following requirements apply:
   1) Tests specified in the applicable safety standard (e.g., IEC 62133-2 sections 7.2 to 7.3) shall be conducted using cells charged under the different upper limit charging voltage.
   2) Relevant documents explaining the reasons for the change of upper limit charging voltage shall be maintained to justify the use of the different voltage as the new upper limit charging voltage.
   3) Examples of situations requiring different upper limit charging voltage include: use of positive active material other than lithium-cobalt-oxide, or changes to the capacity ratio of positive and negative electrodes from the design viewpoint.

d) IF testing under the most severe charging conditions is required, and the maximum charging parameters vary with temperature, the device under test (DUT) shall be charged under the most severe charging parameters as specified in the charging instructions.

e) All specified parameters shall be based on the cell manufacturer's specifications and shall be used in the safety evaluation of the device. These values may vary as the device ages and shall be updated accordingly.

core_requirement:
Battery discharge operations shall comply with the following limits and conditions:
a) Maximum discharge current: The discharge current shall not exceed the maximum discharging current rate specified by the cell/battery manufacturer at any time during discharge operations.
b) Discharge temperature monitoring: During discharging, the battery temperature shall not exceed the highest discharging temperature specified by the manufacturer.
c) Pre-discharge temperature check: If the battery temperature exceeds the highest discharge-start temperature before initiating discharge, discharging shall not be started until the temperature falls within acceptable limits.
d) Continuous compliance: Throughout the entire discharge cycle, both the maximum discharging current and highest discharging temperature limits shall be continuously monitored and enforced.

group_title: Battery Discharge Current and Temperature Limits
regulatory_intent: To prevent battery damage, thermal runaway, and safety hazards by ensuring that discharge operations remain within manufacturer-specified current and temperature limits at all times during battery operation.
consolidated_requirement:
Battery discharge operations shall comply with the following limits and conditions:
a) Maximum discharge current: The discharge current shall not exceed the maximum discharging current rate specified by the cell/battery manufacturer at any time during discharge operations.
b) Discharge temperature monitoring: During discharging, the battery temperature shall not exceed the highest discharging temperature specified by the manufacturer.
c) Pre-discharge temperature check: If the battery temperature exceeds the highest discharge-start temperature before initiating discharge, discharging shall not be started until the temperature falls within acceptable limits.
d) Continuous compliance: Throughout the entire discharge cycle, both the maximum discharging current and highest discharging temperature limits shall be continuously monitored and enforced.

core_requirement:
Battery cells and battery systems shall be designed and tested to withstand short-circuit conditions as follows:

a) External Short-Circuit Testing (Cell Level): Each cell type shall be subjected to external short-circuit testing to verify that the cell does not explode or catch fire when its terminals are short-circuited through an external resistance of less than 0.1 Ω. The test shall be conducted according to the applicable standard's procedure and acceptance criteria.

b) External Short-Circuit Testing (Battery Level): Each battery system shall be subjected to external short-circuit testing to verify that the battery does not explode or catch fire when subjected to an external short circuit. The test shall apply an external resistance of less than 0.1 Ω across the battery terminals.

c) Test Temperature Conditions: Where specified, the battery or cell shall be stabilized at the required test temperature (e.g., 55 ± 2 °C) before applying the short-circuit condition.

d) Test Duration and Observation Period: The short-circuit condition shall be maintained for the specified duration (e.g., 1 hour where specified), followed by an observation period (e.g., 6 hours where specified) to monitor for delayed thermal events or failures.

e) Internal Short-Circuit Testing: Where required by the applicable standard, cells shall be subjected to forced internal short-circuit testing performed in a controlled chamber according to the experimental procedure specified in the standard. The test simulates internal failure modes that could occur due to manufacturing defects, mechanical damage, or degradation.

f) Acceptance Criteria: During and after all short-circuit tests, the cell or battery shall not exhibit:
   - Fire
   - Explosion
   - Rupture
   - Other failures as defined by the applicable standard's acceptance criteria

g) Test Documentation: All short-circuit test results, including temperature profiles, voltage measurements, current measurements, and visual observations, shall be documented and retained as part of the product's compliance records.

core_requirement:
Battery cells and battery systems shall be subjected to a crush test to verify mechanical integrity under compressive forces. The test shall be conducted as follows:

a) Test specimen: The battery cell or battery system shall be tested in the state of charge that represents the worst-case condition for mechanical abuse (typically fully charged state unless otherwise specified).

b) Crush apparatus: A crushing device capable of applying a controlled compressive force shall be used. The crushing surfaces shall be flat and larger than the specimen being crushed.

c) Crush force application: The specimen shall be crushed between two flat surfaces with a force applied gradually until:
   i) A force of 13 kN ± 0.78 kN is reached, OR
   ii) The voltage of the cell or battery drops to 0 V, OR
   iii) The specimen is compressed to 50% of its original thickness,
   whichever occurs first.

d) Force application rate: The crushing force shall be applied at a rate that does not exceed 2 mm/s.

e) Hold duration: Once the termination condition is reached, the force shall be maintained for a duration as specified by the applicable standard.

f) Pass criteria: During the test and for a minimum observation period of 6 hours following the test, the specimen shall not:
   i) Explode
   ii) Catch fire
   iii) Rupture (defined as visible breach of the cell or battery enclosure allowing internal materials to escape)

g) Test orientation: The crush force shall be applied in the orientation most likely to cause failure, typically perpendicular to the largest surface area of the cell or battery.

h) Number of specimens: A minimum of one specimen shall be tested, unless the applicable standard specifies additional test samples.

i) Documentation: Test results shall document the applied force, specimen deformation, voltage behavior, temperature rise (if monitored), and any observations during and after the test period.

core_requirement:
Vibration testing shall be performed on batteries to verify mechanical robustness under transportation and operational conditions:

a) Test specimen preparation: Batteries shall be fully charged in accordance with the manufacturer's specified charging procedure prior to testing.

b) Mounting configuration: Test batteries shall be firmly secured to the platform of the vibration machine without distorting them in such a manner as to faithfully transmit the vibration to the battery.

c) Vibration profile: Test batteries shall be subjected to sinusoidal vibration according to the following parameters:
   - Frequency range: 7 Hz to 200 Hz
   - Displacement amplitude: 0.8 mm (peak-to-peak) from 7 Hz to 18 Hz
   - Acceleration: 1 gn (9.81 m/s²) from 18 Hz to 200 Hz
   - Sweep rate: logarithmic sweep at 1 octave/minute

d) Test duration and orientation: The complete vibration cycle (7 Hz to 200 Hz and back to 7 Hz) shall be repeated 12 times for a total of approximately 3 hours for each of three mutually perpendicular mounting positions. One of the test directions shall be perpendicular to the terminal face.

e) Alternative testing: IF the battery system is intended for electric or hybrid electric vehicle applications, vibration testing may alternatively be conducted in accordance with SAE J2464 (Electric and Hybrid Electric Vehicle Rechargeable Energy Storage System (RESS) Safety and Abuse Testing).

f) Acceptance criteria: Following vibration testing, batteries shall show no evidence of leakage, venting, disassembly, rupture, or fire.

core_requirement:
Venting is defined as the release of excessive internal pressure from a cell, battery, or device under test (DUT) in a manner intended by design to preclude:
a) Rupture of the cell or battery enclosure
b) Explosion
c) Uncontrolled disassembly of the cell or battery components

This definition applies to pressure relief mechanisms that are deliberately incorporated into the battery design as a safety feature to manage overpressure conditions in a controlled manner.

   1) Special disposal instructions about the battery system shall be provided

   3) Store at dry places, away from open flames and food

   5) Do not store close to heating devices; avoid direct sunlight
   6) Preferred storage at 50% of the nominal capacity (if not otherwise specified by the supplier)
   7) Temperature above 70 °C may result in battery leakage and rupture (if not otherwise specified by the supplier)

   3) Do not use a charging device other than the one made for use with your device

   5) Keep battery systems dry and clean
   6) Battery systems shall not be in contact with solvent materials (i.e. dilution, alcohol, oil, anti-corrosive) or chemicals that impact surfaces (i.e. detergents)

core_requirement:
The Device Under Test (DUT) shall be mounted for vibration testing as follows:

a) Mounting Configuration: The DUT shall be securely mounted to a vibration test platform (shaker test bench) in a manner similar to how it is mounted in the end-use Light Electric Vehicle (LEV), according to the designed vehicle mounting position.

b) Mounting Standards Compliance: The mounting shall be performed according to the requirements given in EN 60068-2-47.

c) Test Axis Orientation: The DUT shall be subjected to vibration sequentially along three mutually perpendicular mounting positions (axes). One of the directions of vibration shall be perpendicular to the terminal face.

d) Applicable Vehicle Mass Category: The given test parameters are valid for DUT designed for mounting on sprung masses of a vehicle.

e) Pre-Test State of Charge: The State of Charge (SOC) shall be adjusted to 100% before starting the vibration test.

f) Operational State During Test: While vibrated, each fully charged DUT shall be discharged according to the supplier's recommended minimum discharge voltage at the supplier's recommended maximum continuous discharge current.

clauses.text: Vibration 6.101.1 Purpose The purpose of this test is to verify the safety performance of the DUTs under a mechanical load due to vibration which the DUT will likely experience during the normal operation of the vehicle. 6.101.2 Test procedure Adjust the SOC to 100 % before starting the vibration test. While vibrated, each fully charged DUT shall be discharged according to the supplier’s recommended minimum discharge voltage at the supplier’s recommended maximum continuous discharge current. The given test parameters are valid for DUT designed for mounting on sprung masses of a vehicle. The DUT shall be mounted on a shaker test bench according to the designed vehicle mounting position and according to the requirements given in EN 60068-2-47. The vibration test shall be a sinusoidal waveform with a logarithmic sweep between 7Hz and 200 Hz and back to 7 Hz traversed in 15 min. This cycle shall be repeated 12 times for a total of 3 h for each of three mutually perpendicular mounting positions of the DUT. One of the directions of vibration shall be perpendicular to the terminal face. The logarithmic frequency sweep for DUT with a gross mass of not more than 12 kg is as follows from 7Hz a peak acceleration of 1 gn is maintained until 18Hz is reached. The amplitude is then maintained at 0,8 mm (1,6 mm total excursion) and the frequency increased until a peak acceleration of 8gn occurs (approximately 50 Hz). A peak acceleration of 8 gn is then maintained until the frequency is increased to 200 Hz. The logarithmic frequency sweep for DUT with a gross mass of more than 12 kg, is as follows: from 7 Hz to a peak acceleration of 1 gn is maintained until 18 Hz is reached. The amplitude is then maintained at 0,8 mm (1,6 mm total excursion) and the frequency increased until a peak acceleration of 2 gn occurs (approximately 25 Hz). A peak acceleration of 2 gn is then maintained until the frequency is increased to 200 Hz. After vibration testing, the DUT capacity shall be evaluated by performing two standard cycles according to ISO 12405-1:2011, 6.2, or ISO 12405-2. 6.101.3 Requirements During the test and for a 1 h post-test observation period, the DUT shall exhibit no evidence of leakage or battery enclosure rupture, fire, or explosion, and voltage class B DUT shall maintain an isolation resistance of at least 100 Ω/V.

The DUT shall be securely mounted to a vibration test platform in a manner similar to how it is mounted in the end use LEV. The DUT shall be subjected to a random vibration sequentially along three perpendicular axes as defined in Table 33.1.

core_requirement:
The Battery Management System (BMS) shall implement overcurrent protection functionality meeting the following requirements:

a) Overcurrent Protection Function (if implemented as option 2): The overcurrent protection function shall disconnect the short circuit current when activated.

b) Safety Performance During Overcurrent Protection Activation: When the overcurrent protection function activates to disconnect short circuit current, the battery system shall not exhibit any evidence of:
   1) Disassembly of battery components
   2) Fire or flames

c) Temperature Limits During Overcurrent Event: The temperature of the battery casing shall not exceed 150 °C within 6 hours following overcurrent protection activation.

d) Overload Operating Range Definition: The BMS design shall distinguish between two current conditions:
   1) Condition 1 (Overload): Current levels above the specified maximum discharge current of the battery, but below the BMS overcurrent protection activation threshold as specified in the applicable overcurrent protection requirements (e.g., sections 26.3–26.5 of the governing standard)
   2) Overcurrent Protection Activation: Current levels at or above the BMS overcurrent protection threshold, triggering disconnection per requirement (a)
